results_summary: The study identified Bacillus atrophaeus B1 as a highly nicotine-tolerant strain capable of degrading nicotine at a rate of 46.36%, with key genes and metabolic pathways involved in the process. Antibiotic treatment reduced nicotine tolerance in S. frugiperda, which was restored upon reinfection with B. atrophaeus B1.
population_specificity: Spodoptera frugiperda (fall armyworm) larvae
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of 2 g/L nicotine

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess differences in alcohol consumption, alcohol brief intervention receipt, and alcohol reduction attempts based on smoking status and non-combustible nicotine use.
results_summary: The study found that combustible nicotine use was strongly associated with higher alcohol consumption and risky drinking, while non-combustible nicotine use showed a weaker association. Smokers were more likely to receive alcohol brief interventions and attempt alcohol reduction if trying to quit smoking.
population_specificity: Adults in England (n=188,878), including current, former, and never smokers, as well as users of non-combustible nicotine products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acid sphingomyelinase (Asm) and ceramide signaling mediate nicotine-induced Nlrp3 inflammasome activation and podocyte damage.
results_summary: Nicotine increased Asm expression, ceramide production, and podocyte damage markers, which were attenuated by amitriptyline pretreatment. Nicotine also increased cell permeability, oxidative stress, and apoptosis, effects that were similarly reduced by amitriptyline.
population_specificity: Podocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether introducing an inhaled form of Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) improved acceptability and reduced aggression among tobacco smokers in a high dependency mental health unit.
results_summary: NRT use increased from 26% to 33% after introducing the inhaled form, and its use was associated with a significant reduction in aggression. Overall aggression was lower in the second year, suggesting improved acceptance and effectiveness of NRT.
population_specificity: Tobacco smokers admitted to a high dependency mental health unit at a tertiary metropolitan hospital, with 71% having a history of violence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanisms and potential biomarkers associated with nicotine and BaP exposure in lung cancer patients.
results_summary: The study identified 163 differentially expressed genes related to nicotine and BaP exposure, with CLDN5, DNASE1L3, and GPR37 being independent prognostic factors. High-risk patients showed poorer survival outcomes, and the genes were linked to immune responses, cell adhesion, and DNA methylation.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients with exposure to nicotine and BaP.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how nicotine interacts with HIV's gp120 protein in human microglia cells, focusing on mitochondrial protein regulation and amyloid precursor protein release.
results_summary: Nicotine and gp120 increased mitochondrial protein expression (PHB2, cyt c, MFN2) while decreasing FIS1, enlarged mitochondrial networks, and promoted amyloid precursor protein (APP) peptide release from microglia. These interactions suggest nicotine may exacerbate neuroinflammatory signaling in HIV-infected individuals.
population_specificity: Human microglia cells (HMC3) expressing CCR5 and nAChRs, modeling HIV-infected individuals who smoke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine perceptions of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) and e-cigarettes among low-income smokers interested in quitting or reducing smoking.
results_summary: The study identified three subgroups based on perceptions: "adopters" (positive views), "doubters of e-cigarettes" (questioned e-cigarette effectiveness), and "resistors" (negative views). Factors like age, financial difficulties, mental health, and prior quit attempts influenced these perceptions.
population_specificity: Low-income smokers interested in quitting or reducing smoking, not currently using e-cigarettes (n=167).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the readiness of adult smokers to stop smoking when adopting ENDS (JUUL), the association between readiness and switching away from smoking, and the role of JUUL use frequency in switching.
results_summary: The study found that 70% of those planning to quit within 7 days switched to ENDS by Month 24, while even those never planning to quit achieved 51% abstinence. Daily ENDS use was strongly associated with higher switching rates, but frequency of use did not mediate readiness to quit.
population_specificity: 17,393 adult cigarette smokers (55.4% male) who purchased a JUUL Starter Kit.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency of JUUL use categorized as daily, frequent [≥20 days/month], or infrequent).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of immersive (VR) and non-immersive (2D) cue-reactivity paradigms in triggering nicotine cravings among smokers and non-smokers.
results_summary: Smokers experienced increased cravings after exposure to nicotine-related cues, with higher self-reported cravings in VR compared to 2D. VR also elicited stronger physiological responses (skin conductance) in smokers, and participants rated VR as more realistic for simulating real-life situations.
population_specificity: 23 smokers (15 female, mean age 23.2) and 22 non-smokers (13 female, mean age 23.7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess spatial variability in nicotine exposure using wastewater-based epidemiology and evaluate the impact of physicochemical wastewater parameters on observed differences.
results_summary: Nicotine metabolites were quantifiable in all wastewater samples, with population-normalized daily mass loads varying between treatment plants. Adjusting for wastewater temperature eliminated observed spatial variations in nicotine metabolite levels.
population_specificity: Municipal wastewater from four treatment plants in Essen, Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of oral nicotine pouches in helping people transition away from combustible tobacco use and other non-combustible tobacco/commercial nicotine products.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as it describes a protocol for a future Cochrane Review.
population_specificity: People using combustible tobacco or other non-combustible tobacco/commercial nicotine products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanisms of nicotine-exacerbated renal damage in hypertensive rats and the potential intervention effect of negative air ions (NAIs).
results_summary: Nicotine worsened systolic blood pressure and renal damage, increased oxidative stress, and activated the TGF-β/Smad pathway in hypertensive rats. NAIs intervention reduced oxidative damage and downregulated the TGF-β/Smad pathway, mitigating nicotine-induced renal damage.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR), 8-week-old males.
effective_dosage: 1.5 mg/kg nicotine exposure; NAIs at 4.5 × 10⁴ to 5 × 10⁴ NAIs/cm³ for 6 hours/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining nicotine replacement with brief behavioral support effectively reduces cigarette use in opioid-dependent individuals receiving opioid agonist therapy.
results_summary: The intervention group had 2.07 times higher odds of reducing cigarette use by at least 50% compared to the control group, demonstrating significant effectiveness in reducing smoking among opioid-dependent participants.
population_specificity: Opioid-dependent individuals receiving opioid agonist therapy and smoking at least 1 cigarette per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the real-world effectiveness of 1-week nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) sampling combined with counseling on smoking abstinence in Chinese women.
results_summary: The study found that 1-week NRT sampling combined with counseling significantly increased smoking abstinence and reduction rates compared to counseling alone, particularly benefiting women with lower socioeconomic status. Users of <1 week showed no significant improvement over non-users.
population_specificity: 545 Chinese women (mean age 37.7 years) enrolled in the Women Quit program in Hong Kong from 2006 to 2023.
effective_dosage: 1-week free NRT sampling (exact dosage not specified).
study_duration: 1-week NRT sampling with follow-ups at 3 and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nicotine alone or in combination with ethanol could restore dopamine levels and tyrosine hydroxylase activity in MPTP-induced Parkinson's disease model mice.
results_summary: Nicotine alone (1.0 and 2.0 mg/kg) reversed MPTP-induced dopamine depletion, increased dopamine metabolites, and restored tyrosine hydroxylase activity. Co-administration with ethanol showed additive effects, further enhancing dopamine-related markers.
population_specificity: C57BL/6N mice with MPTP-induced Parkinson's-like dopamine depletion.
study_duration: Brain samples collected 1 hour after treatment.
interactions: Additive effect noted with ethanol co-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of auricular acupuncture-related therapies (AARTs) in managing nicotine dependence (ND) compared to nicotine replacement therapy (NRT).
results_summary: AART significantly reduced the Minnesota Nicotine Withdrawal Scale score (MNWS) compared to NRT but showed no significant differences in other measures like cessation rate or daily smoking volume. AART was associated with fewer adverse events than NRT.
population_specificity: 1032 patients with nicotine dependence.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate nicotine's effects on human platelet function and its pharmacological mechanisms, particularly its potential as a hemostatic agent.
results_summary: Nicotine was found to fully activate platelets, promoting aggregation, granule release, adhesion, spreading, and plaque retraction by enhancing intracellular calcium levels and activating the PAR4 receptor signaling pathway, leading to phosphorylation of PI3K, AKT, and ERK1/2 proteins. PAR4 inhibitors reversed these effects.
population_specificity: Human platelets (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the age- and genotype-dependent effects of chronic nicotine administration on cognitive function and molecular pathways in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Nicotine improved contextual fear memory in older Alzheimer's model mice but impaired nest-building ability and cued fear memory in healthy older mice. It modulated neuropeptide signaling and reduced astrocyte activation in Alzheimer's model mice while disrupting certain pathways in healthy mice.
population_specificity: Presenilin 1/2 double knockout (DKO) mice (an amyloid-β-independent Alzheimer's model) and wild-type (WT) mice at 3-month-old and 8-month-old ages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether low-dose nicotine could protect against ischemic stroke-induced blood-brain barrier (BBB) damage and brain injury by exploring key molecular pathways.
results_summary: Pretreatment with 12 μg/ml nicotine significantly reduced BBB damage and brain injury in mice subjected to ischemic stroke, and in vitro studies showed nicotine reduced endothelial cell permeability under stress. RNA-seq identified TGF-β and Wnt signaling pathways as key mediators, with nicotine's effects dependent on α7 nAChR activation.
population_specificity: Mice (in vivo) and hCMEC/D3 endothelial cells (in vitro)
effective_dosage: 12 μg/ml in drinking water (in vivo), pretreatment for 48 hours (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of randomizing relapsed smokers to cytisine or combination nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) after cardiac hospital admission and compare their acceptability, efficacy, and safety.
results_summary: The study focuses on feasibility outcomes like recruitment rates and treatment completion, with secondary outcomes including smoking cessation rates and adverse events. It highlights cytisine's potential appeal due to its shorter regimen and natural composition but does not report specific nicotine-related results.
population_specificity: Relapsed smokers recently admitted to a cardiac hospital (University of Ottawa Heart Institute).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the feasibility and effectiveness of a brief educational intervention to increase primary care physicians' prescribing of combination nicotine replacement therapy (cNRT) for tobacco cessation.
results_summary: The study found that a 30-minute virtual training significantly increased cNRT prescribing by primary care physicians, with the number of patients receiving cNRT prescriptions rising from 9% to 23% and the number of prescribing physicians increasing from 23% to 37%. Post-training, 93% of physicians reported increased confidence, 91% had favorable attitudes, and 88% intended to prescribe cNRT.
population_specificity: Primary care physicians in a large integrated health system in California.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess private dental practitioners' attitudes, practices, and barriers regarding tobacco cessation counseling and Nicotine Replacement Therapy (NRT) in North India.
results_summary: While 69% of practitioners offered tobacco cessation counseling, only 20.4% practiced NRT. Most (52%) believed NRT combined with counseling improved quitting success, but 98% cited lack of formal training as a barrier.
population_specificity: Private dental practitioners in North India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors that predict the use of nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) patches in rural populations to optimize smoking cessation interventions.
results_summary: Greater confidence in quitting predicted higher NRT patch use, while living in remote areas and past substance use predicted lower use. The study suggests that understanding these factors could improve the effectiveness of mass NRT distribution programs.
population_specificity: Rural-dwelling cigarette smokers in Canada.
effective_dosage: 5-week supply of NRT patches (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether HMGB1 contributes to nicotine-induced podocyte injury and explored the role of TLR4 activation in this process.
results_summary: Nicotine increased HMGB1 expression and release, reduced podocyte functional proteins (podocin and nephrin), and elevated desmin expression and cell permeability. Glycyrrhizin (Gly) and TLR4 inhibition attenuated these nicotine-induced effects.
population_specificity: Podocytes (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ghrelin and GHRP-6 on horizontal and vertical activity in rats exposed to chronic nicotine treatment followed by acute nicotine withdrawal.
results_summary: Nicotine-treated rats showed hyperactivity after 12 hours of withdrawal, which was reduced by ghrelin and GHRP-6, and hypoactivity after 24 hours, which was reversed by the same peptides.
population_specificity: Male and female Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 2 mg/kg nicotine (intraperitoneal, twice daily) and 1 μg/2 μL ghrelin or GHRP-6 (intracerebroventricular, once daily)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify sesquiterpene compounds from Cinnamomum that could act as antagonists for human nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRα3) and evaluate their potential for nicotine replacement therapy.
results_summary: The study found that Dihydroxyeudesmene, Gibberodione, and Germacrene-E exhibited the highest binding affinities to nAChRα3, suggesting potential efficacy in competing with nicotine. Molecular dynamics simulations confirmed the stability of these compounds, though further in vitro, in vivo, and clinical studies are needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (in silico study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether electroacupuncture (EA) could mitigate perinatal nicotine exposure (PNE)-induced pulmonary dysplasia in offspring by modulating maternal gut microbiota and short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs).
results_summary: EA increased maternal gut microbiota richness and beneficial bacteria abundance, elevated serum SCFA levels in mothers and offspring, and improved offspring lung function and morphology, but these benefits were lost when maternal gut microbiota was depleted.
population_specificity: Pregnant rats and their offspring exposed to nicotine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of nicotine on alveolar repair in rats after tooth extraction and assess the effectiveness of ozonised water and low-power laser therapy as adjuvants.
results_summary: Nicotine negatively affected the healing and bone repair process in tooth extraction sites. However, ozonised water and low-power laser therapy improved bone repair even in nicotine-exposed rats.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (Rattus Norvegicus)
study_duration: 21 days after tooth extraction (7 days pre-extraction nicotine exposure + 14 days post-extraction)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the use of adjuvant treatment options (e.g., aromatherapy, exercise, hypnosis, acupuncture) in smoking cessation counseling among experts.
results_summary: More than half of the surveyed experts (66.3%) employed at least one adjuvant treatment option, with exercise, hypnosis, and acupuncture being the most common. The study suggests adjuvant treatments are important in counseling but highlights a need for further discussion and inclusion in training curricula.
population_specificity: 88 experts (average age 53, 71% female) with an average of 14 years of experience in smoking cessation counseling.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foliar application of 24-epibrassinolide (EBR) enhances nicotine content in flue-cured tobacco leaves under low-temperature conditions during the mature stage.
results_summary: Foliar spraying of EBR increased nicotine content in tobacco leaves, with the 0.2 mg·L-1 concentration showing the most significant improvement (11.11% and 19.90% increases in middle and upper leaves, respectively). Combining EBR with other compounds (α-Cyclodextrin, Tween 80, CaCl2, ZnSO4·7H2O, KH2PO4) further enhanced cold resistance and prolonged EBR's effectiveness.
population_specificity: 'Yunyan 87' flue-cured tobacco plants during the mature stage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the neurobiological mechanisms of nicotine's effects on feeding and body weight, focusing on nervous system regulation, energy expenditure, hormones, and gut microbiota.
results_summary: The study found that nicotine influences feeding and body weight through neuronal signaling molecules (e.g., AMPK, κOR), energy homeostasis-related neurons (e.g., POMC, AgRP), and neural circuits involving the hypothalamus, reward system, and gut-brain axis. These mechanisms suggest potential therapeutic applications for smoking cessation and obesity treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of various nicotine consumption modalities on complication rates after Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS).
results_summary: Patients with any history of nicotine use had an 8.5% absolute risk of complications compared to 3.1% for non-users, representing a relative risk of 2.75. Smoked tobacco use was a statistically significant factor for complications, while risks from smokeless nicotine products remain unclear.
population_specificity: 404 patients undergoing Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe e-liquid flavor preferences and nicotine concentration usage over 6 months in smokers attempting to quit using electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS).
results_summary: At 6 months, exclusive e-cigarette users preferred more fruity flavors and used lower nicotine concentrations compared to dual users. Initial nicotine concentrations were similar between groups but decreased over time.
population_specificity: Adult smokers consuming at least five cigarettes per day.
effective_dosage: Choice of 4 nicotine concentrations (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether nicotine could reduce behavioral deficits and pathological changes in a mouse model of Parkinson's disease induced by human alpha-synuclein preformed fibers.
results_summary: Nicotine significantly reduced pathological alpha-synuclein accumulation, apoptosis, and neuroinflammation in mice, while also improving behavioral deficits such as memory impairment, motor deficits, and anxiety-like behavior.
population_specificity: Mice injected with human alpha-synuclein preformed fibers to model Parkinson's disease-like phenotypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the Rodent Electronic Nicotine Delivery System (RENDS) as a preclinical model for nicotine aerosol self-administration.
results_summary: The study confirmed that RENDS effectively sequesters nicotine aerosol in the nose port, demonstrated robust self-administration of flavored nicotine aerosol in rats, and resulted in high blood cotinine levels and withdrawal symptoms.
population_specificity: Rats (preclinical model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of nicotine pouch use among youth and adults in Great Britain and identify associated factors.
results_summary: The study found that nicotine pouch use doubled among adults from 2020 to 2024, reaching 5.4% for ever use and 1.0% for current use, while 3.3% of youth reported ever use. Use was associated with younger age, male gender, and other addictive product use.
population_specificity: Adults (18+) and youth (11-18 years) in Great Britain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic disruptions caused by nicotine exposure and evaluate resveratrol's potential protective effects.
results_summary: Nicotine exposure caused significant weight loss, elevated glucose levels, altered lipid profiles, organ damage, and increased inflammation. Resveratrol treatment mitigated these effects by improving metabolic balance and reducing inflammation.
population_specificity: Mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a high-dose transdermal nicotine patch (21 mg/24 h) could reduce postoperative pain and opioid requirements in abstinent tobacco smokers undergoing spinal fusion.
results_summary: The study found that the nicotine group had lower postoperative pain scores and reduced morphine consumption compared to the placebo group, with significant correlations between nicotine levels, cigarette use, and pain/opioid requirements.
population_specificity: Abstinent tobacco smokers undergoing single-level spinal fusion (n=100).
study_duration: Applied 24 hours before surgery until 48 hours after surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of nicotine on transthyretin expression, secretion, and uptake by hepatocytes, and whether nicotine altered the uptake of transthyretin-bound soluble endoglin.
results_summary: Nicotine increased transthyretin mRNA and protein levels in hepatocytes and enhanced the uptake of both transthyretin and soluble endoglin. The transthyretin-soluble endoglin complex was taken up via LRP1, though LRP1 protein levels remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Cultured hepatocytes (rodent-derived, based on prior context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the nicotine metabolite ratio (NMR) could predict successful smoking cessation or varenicline intolerance in people with HIV who smoke.
results_summary: The study found no significant correlation between NMR and smoking behaviors, nicotine dependence, or cessation success. NMR also did not predict varenicline intolerance.
population_specificity: People with HIV (PWH) who smoke cigarettes (mean age 52.9, 62.3% male, 91.0% Black).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the methods used by US adults to stop smoking, focusing on the effectiveness of nicotine products, particularly e-cigarettes, compared to other methods.
results_summary: The study found that nicotine products, especially e-cigarettes (used alone or in combination), were the most popular and effective methods for smoking cessation, with 53.9% of successful quitters using them. Prescription drugs and non-nicotine methods were less popular, and successful quitters were more likely to be younger, degree-educated, and e-cigarette users.
population_specificity: US adults who self-reported having stopped smoking for 6+ months in the last year or tried but failed to stop (N=27,651, with 1,735 in the cessation analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of glucocorticoid receptors (GRs) and nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) in the acute rewarding effects of nicotine using an intracranial self-stimulation (ICSS) procedure in rats.
results_summary: Nicotine enhanced the rewarding effects of ICSS and had stimulant properties, lowering brain reward thresholds and decreasing response latencies in both male and female rats. The GR antagonist mifepristone did not affect nicotine's reward-enhancing effects but increased response latencies, while the nAChR antagonist mecamylamine blocked nicotine's effects, indicating nAChRs mediate nicotine's rewarding effects.
population_specificity: Adult male and female rats with ICSS electrodes implanted in the medial forebrain bundle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of Connexin 43 (Cx43) in nicotine-induced proliferation and migration of pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells (PASMCs) and its mechanism involving ERK1/2 phosphorylation.
results_summary: Nicotine increased Cx43 expression and promoted PASMC proliferation and migration via ERK1/2 phosphorylation in mice; downregulation of Cx43 reduced these effects by inhibiting ERK1/2 activation.
population_specificity: Tagln-Cre; Cx43+/+, Cx43flox/+, and Cx43flox/flox mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the regulatory framework and clinical guidelines for using nicotine-containing vapes as a smoking cessation aid under medical supervision in Australia.
results_summary: The study found that therapeutic vapes may be considered for individuals unable to quit smoking using first-line therapies, with clinical review recommended after 1 week and a maximum recommended duration of 12 months. Adverse effects such as cough, irritated throat, headache, or nausea were noted, and dual use of vapes and conventional cigarettes was discouraged.
population_specificity: Individuals requiring smoking cessation or treatment for nicotine dependence under medical supervision.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of nicotine exposure via vape aerosol inhalation on myocardial response to infarction injury.
results_summary: Nicotine exposure via vape aerosol worsened contractile performance after myocardial infarction, irrespective of sex. Vape aerosol alone increased nonmyocyte interstitial cell accumulation post-infarction, but this effect was not observed with nicotine-containing aerosol.
population_specificity: Mice subjected to acute myocardial infarction injury.
effective_dosage: 5 mg/mL nicotine in flavored vape juice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combustible cigarettes (CCs) and electronic nicotine delivery systems (ENDS) on the viability, proliferation, and immunomodulatory capacity of periodontal ligament-derived mesenchymal stem cells (PDL-MSCs).
results_summary: CCs caused more severe impairment in PDL-MSC viability and proliferation compared to ENDS, while also promoting a proinflammatory immune response. ENDS showed less severe effects but still reduced regenerative capacity and potentially induced an immunosuppressive response.
population_specificity: Periodontal ligament-derived mesenchymal stem cells (PDL-MSCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of combination nicotine replacement therapy (c-NRT) for smoking cessation among people with HIV (PWH) in South Africa.
results_summary: The study found that adding c-NRT (nicotine patches and gum) to behavioral counseling increased smoking abstinence at 6 months (15% vs. 10%), though the difference was not statistically significant. The results align with c-NRT's performance in the general population.
population_specificity: People with HIV (PWH) who smoke in South Africa.
effective_dosage: Not specified (nicotine patches augmented by nicotine gum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction between α4β2 nAChR and dopamine receptors, particularly D3R, and how nicotine exposure during adolescence affects nicotine reward and relapse in adulthood.
results_summary: Nicotine exposure in adolescent rats increased α4β2 nAChR and D3R expression, with elevated D3R levels persisting into adulthood. D3R knockout mice showed reduced nicotine reward effects, and cellular studies linked D3R upregulation to a signaling cascade involving Src, Syk, PKC, and NF-κB.
population_specificity: Adolescent rats and mice (wild-type and D3R knockout).
interactions: Interaction between α4β2 nAChR and dopamine D2/D3 receptors noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether crocin could improve learning and memory impairment caused by withdrawal from concurrent nicotine and ethanol use in adolescent male rats.
results_summary: Crocin treatment effectively prevented memory impairment induced by nicotine-ethanol withdrawal, as shown by behavioral tests, and ameliorated biochemical alterations in inflammatory, oxidative, and cholinergic parameters. The effect was dose-dependent and comparable to bupropion and naloxone co-administration at high doses.
population_specificity: Adolescent male Wistar rats
effective_dosage: Three doses of crocin (specific amounts not provided)
interactions: Concurrent use of nicotine and ethanol, and comparison with bupropion and naloxone co-administration

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the in vitro toxicological effects of modern oral nicotine pouch products (ONPs) compared to combustible cigarettes and snus, focusing on mutagenicity, genotoxicity, and cytotoxicity.
results_summary: Most ONPs (MO 1-7, ZYN wintergreen, General Snus white mint) showed no mutagenicity, genotoxicity, or cytotoxicity, while the combustible cigarette was positive in all assays. MO-8 was negative for mutagenicity but positive for genotoxicity and cytotoxicity at much higher concentrations than cigarettes.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human subjects specified).
study_duration: Not specified (in vitro assays typically short-term).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety and efficacy of smoking cessation medications, including nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), among individuals with current or past major depressive disorder (MDD) versus those without psychiatric disorders.
results_summary: The study found that NRT was not more effective than placebo for individuals with current MDD, though it was generally safe. Varenicline showed greater efficacy than NRT and placebo, particularly in individuals with current MDD.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-75 with past MDD (N=2,174), current MDD (N=451), or no psychiatric disorders (N=4,028).
study_duration: 12 weeks of pharmacotherapy followed by a 12-week assessment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of repeated high-dose nicotine treatment on brain anatomy and behavior in adolescent and adult male rats.
results_summary: Nicotine treatment in adolescent rats led to reduced gray matter volume in the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC), increased oxidative stress, elevated microglial activity, and altered synaptic markers, suggesting structural and connectivity deficits. Adult rats showed abolished body weight gain but no significant brain changes.
population_specificity: Adolescent and adult male rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of an EHR-automated population health management intervention for smoking cessation among low-income adult smokers.
results_summary: The PHM intervention resulted in 16.3% abstinence at 28 weeks, compared to 6.4% in the enhanced usual care group, with higher treatment engagement (25.8%) and utilization (21.6%) in the PHM arm.
population_specificity: Adult smokers (64.7% women, 82.1% African American/Black, 8.4% Hispanic/Latino) from a federally qualified health center in Chicago.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in urinary biomarkers among adult tobacco users switching between e-cigarettes and cigarettes to assess potential harm reduction.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in harmful biomarkers when users transitioned from exclusive cigarette or dual use to exclusive e-cigarette use, but increases when e-cigarette users switched to cigarettes or dual use. Switching from cigarettes to dual use did not significantly reduce harmful biomarkers.
population_specificity: US adults who voluntarily provided biospecimens, including exclusive cigarette smokers, exclusive e-cigarette users, and dual users.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the characteristics of nicotine poisoning-related content on TikTok, particularly under the hashtag #nicsick, to understand how social media portrays and influences nicotine-related adverse events.
results_summary: Over half of the analyzed TikTok videos discussed firsthand or secondhand reports of nicotine poisoning symptoms, with 43% of users self-reporting adverse events like vomiting. Content portraying active vaping behavior was prevalent, and users posting nicotine sickness-related content had significantly higher follower counts.
population_specificity: TikTok users, primarily aged 16-24, posting or engaging with content under the #nicsick hashtag.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether extending indoor smoking restrictions to include electronic cigarettes (ECs) impacts EC use and cigarette smoking among US adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between indoor vaping restrictions and adult EC use or cigarette smoking, with non-significant results across socio-demographic subgroups.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-54 living in US counties with pre-2010 comprehensive indoor smoking laws.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of vitamin D supplementation on mental health symptoms, nicotine misuse, and metabolic disease biomarkers in individuals with tobacco use disorder.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding nicotine's effects, only mentioning the study's focus on vitamin D supplementation in smokers.
population_specificity: 60 cigarette smokers with tobacco use disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nicotine supplementation improves cognitive function, heart rate variability, and archery performance in professional archers.
results_summary: Nicotine supplementation improved cognitive performance (faster correct rejection time and grooved pegboard test completion), reduced saliva α-amylase activity, decreased HRV, and increased archery scores compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Eleven college archers.
study_duration: Acute intervention (effects measured at 30 minutes post-intake).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplemental n-3 LCPUFAs could reduce tobacco-related adverse pregnancy outcomes and/or increase smoking cessation in pregnant smokers.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that n-3 LCPUFA supplementation may reduce preterm labor risk and nicotine cravings in pregnant smokers, but results are pending as the study is ongoing.
population_specificity: Pregnant smokers between 12 and 24 weeks' gestation in Middle Tennessee.
study_duration: From enrollment (12-24 weeks' gestation) until 6 weeks after delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between regular smoking initiation before age 21 and nicotine dependence and cessation behaviors in US adult smokers.
results_summary: The study found that regular smoking initiation at ages 18-20 was linked to higher odds of nicotine dependence and lower odds of attempting or intending to quit, similar to outcomes seen with initiation before age 18. This suggests delaying access to tobacco products until after age 21 could reduce addiction and promote cessation.
population_specificity: US adult smokers (data from the 2014-2015 Tobacco Use Supplement to the Current Population Survey).

study_goal: The study does not specifically evaluate nicotine but mentions its screening as part of prepregnancy counseling.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about nicotine's effects, only recommending screening for its use among reproductive-aged individuals.
population_specificity: Reproductive-aged individuals, including heterosexual, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, asexual, and gender nonconforming individuals.

study_goal: The study aimed to outline the importance of prepregnancy counseling, including assessing nicotine use among reproductive-aged individuals.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about nicotine's effects but emphasizes the need to screen for nicotine use during prepregnancy counseling.
population_specificity: Reproductive-aged individuals, including heterosexual, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, asexual, and gender nonconforming individuals.

study_goal: The study does not specifically aim to determine the safety or efficacy of nicotine but rather emphasizes the importance of assessing nicotine use during prepregnancy counseling.
results_summary: The abstract does not report specific findings about nicotine's effects but highlights the need to screen for nicotine use as part of prepregnancy care.
population_specificity: Reproductive-aged individuals, including heterosexual, lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, intersex, asexual, and gender nonconforming individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel micronutrient supplement could assist with smoking cessation by reducing nicotine dependence and cigarette consumption.
results_summary: The study found that micronutrients reduced cigarette consumption compared to placebo, with 28% of the micronutrient group quitting versus 18% in the placebo group, though continuous abstinence rates did not significantly differ. No serious adverse events were reported, and side effects were comparable between groups.
population_specificity: 107 participants (57 in micronutrient group, 50 in placebo group) attempting to quit smoking.
effective_dosage: Up to 12 capsules/day during a 4-week pre-quit phase.
study_duration: 4-week pre-quit phase followed by a 12-week quit phase.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether aloe polysaccharide (APS), propolis, or their mixture could enhance the urinary excretion of nicotine and BaP in smokers.
results_summary: The study found that supplementation with APS, propolis, or their mixture significantly increased urinary excretion of cotinine (a nicotine metabolite) and BaP, while reducing creatinine, glucose, and total bilirubin levels. These results suggest potential detoxifying effects of the supplements on nicotine and tobacco-related carcinogens.
population_specificity: Smokers consuming ≥20 cigarettes/day (10 people per subgroup).
effective_dosage: 600 mg/day of APS, 600 mg/day of propolis, or 600 mg/day of a mixture (420 mg APS + 180 mg propolis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of financial incentives versus usual care on smoking abstinence, use of counseling and nicotine replacement therapy (NRT), and quality of life in hospitalized smokers.
results_summary: The study found that financial incentives combined with enhanced usual care (including NRT) could improve smoking cessation rates and increase the use of evidence-based therapies, with outcomes measured at 2 and 6 months. The oral microbiome substudy also sought to assess changes in microbiome composition due to smoking cessation.
population_specificity: Hospitalized smokers from the Veterans Affairs New York Harbor Healthcare System, with nonsmoking controls matched for the microbiome substudy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (NRT access provided, but exact dosage not detailed).
study_duration: Follow-up at 2 weeks, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months post-discharge.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of smokeless nicotine on physiological responses and exercise performance.
results_summary: Nicotine significantly increased heart rate, blood pressure, and blood flow in multiple studies, but beneficial effects on exercise performance were limited to improved leg extensor torque and endurance performance in one study each. Anaerobic performance was mostly unaffected or decreased.
population_specificity: Not specified (general exercise performance context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vitamin C supplementation could mitigate the DNA methylation changes in offspring caused by maternal smoking during pregnancy and whether these changes were linked to respiratory outcomes.
results_summary: Vitamin C supplementation restored 69.03% of CpGs with methylation differences toward nonsmoker levels and showed significant associations with improved respiratory outcomes, suggesting a systemic and persistent effect on offspring DNA methylation.
population_specificity: Pregnant smokers and their offspring.
